content:
None of the test cases involve an x coordinate inside the square while the y coordinate is outside the square. Because of this, it is possible to write code that passes all test cases, but fails Validator #4. This can be accomplished with the following typo when checking the square:

Award 5 pts if abs(x) <= size/2 and abs(y) >= size/2
Added "write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

There seems to be a lot of input data, not all of them strictly necessary.

The point is to check whether coordinates fall within various shapes, size doesn't seem to matter much.
The list of competitor names is somewhat redundant, you could simply give the number of rounds and players followed by the list of throws.

I second JBM on the tests.
Attributing the exact same throws to different players so that the scores change while the darts land on the exact same spots would be quite enough to prevent hard-coded solutions. Here you run the risk of frustrating people with red validators after passing all tests.

The test/validator split seems pretty haphazard.

The intended use is to have each pair test the same family of case, though some obfuscation might be tolerated on the validator side.

Here the parallel is... non-obvious to me. They all seem to be testing completely different aspects, with no relationship.
As Uljahn mentioned, the stub is missing the throws.
"In the event of a tie" Statement does not need to be repeated, I suggest to remove it from the first block to lighten it.
The stub should be fixed i guess.
Thank you sir, I've corrected the code stub.
Agreed, I've removed it.

I'm having some trouble with the syntax.  I've tried these two lines:
loop M*N read throwData:string(100)
loop M loop N read throwData:string(100)

Both produce an "invalid stub generator" when attempting to save the problem definition.  There any chance you've experienced this or could provide some guidance here, sir?
Yeah, yeah the parallel is not obvious because there isn't one.  I didn't know the difference between test cases and validators.  I'll alter these to match the definition you've given.

Yeah you're right, not all the input data is strictly necessary.  I would argue size is necessary because its critical in determining the bounds of the geometry about 0.

And you're right here too, I could alter the input to be more terse.  If you feel strongly it should be done that way I'll change it.  However I would argue the current definition potentially requires users to more carefully read the problem requirements as throw order is not tied to initial name order, which I view as a positive thing.

Finally I agree on tests with both JBM and you.  I've altered the tests and validators based on your feedback.  Thanks for your assistance!
Also edited to fix a few (minor) formatting issues (in particular in I/O & Constraints sections).

I've just added 4 more pairs of cases (#5 to #8).

I've also amended the author's solution, which doesn't work correctly when SIZE is odd (because SIZE/2 when assigned to an `int`-type variable would become rounded down).

These were just suggestions. The important point is validation, but that should be easy to fix.

Personally I like it better when you don't need to do more bookkeeping than necessary, but I suppose that's debatable. 

Btw. it might be better to state explicitely that the order used for tie breaks comes from the name list instead of "input order" (that might apply to turns as well).

Good point, you're right.  Being more specific about "input order" would make things much more clear.  I've reworded that, and also refer to the initial set of names as the 'name list' in the input definition as well.
Thanks greatly for your needed feedback.  I've corrected my test/validators to reflect what you've indicated.
Thanks for the update, it's much better now!
I guess you could provide "Total number of records" (T = M*N) instead of the "Number of rounds" (M).

Hmm, yeah good idea.  That would require me to update all test cases, and the solution.  Before that I'm reaching out to coderHS@codingame.com to see if they can provide some assistance.  The source languages seem to reflect the stub correctly... seems odd submitting would error given that.
Because I have no patience I went ahead and updated the problem definition as you suggested.  Thanks greatly for the advice.
